Math_Problem: A rubber band is 4 inches long. An ant begins at the left end. Every minute, the ant walks one inch along rightwards along the rubber band, but then the band is stretched (uniformly) by one inch. For what value of $n$ will the ant reach the right end during the $n$th minute? Instead of determining the minute during which the ant reaches the right end, simply find $p$, where $p$ is the portion of the rubber band's length traversed by the ant during the first minute accounting for the uniform stretch. Let $s = p + \frac{23}{4}$. $s$ students taking a test sit in a row of seats with aisles only on the two sides of the row. If they finish the test at random times, what is the probability that some student will have to pass by another student to get to an aisle?

Synthesised_By.A3322: A rubber band is 4 inches long. An ant begins at the left end. Every minute, the ant walks one inch along rightwards along the rubber band, but then the band is stretched (uniformly) by one inch. For what value of $n$ will the ant reach the right end during the $n$th minute? Instead of determining the minute during which the ant reaches the right end, simply find $s = p + \frac{23}{4}$, where $p$ is the portion of the rubber band's length traversed by the ant during the first minute accounting for the uniform stretch.

Synthesised_By.A355: Six students taking a test sit in a row of seats with aisles only on the two sides of the row. If they finish the test at random times, what is the probability that some student will have to pass by another student to get to an aisle?

A3322: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations

A355: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Counting Methods -> Combinations

Claims.expr: smallest n such that sum_{k=1}^{n-1} 1/(k+3) < 1 <= sum_{k=1}^n 1/(k+3)
ant walks 1 inch per minute rightwards from left end
after each minute's walk, band is stretched uniformly by 1 inch
fraction added during minute m: 1/(m+3)
ant reaches right end during nth minute iff f(n-1) < 1 <= f(n)
P(some student has to pass by another | 6 students in row, random finish times) = ?
6 students sit in a row with aisles on both ends
finish times random, so leaving order uniform random permutation of 6 students
no student passes by another iff each leaver is at an end of the remaining row when they leave
initially, remaining students form a consecutive row of 6 with 2 ends
removing an end student leaves a consecutive row with 2 ends
P(first leaver at end) = 2/6
after first end removed, remaining row of 5 with 2 ends
P(second leaver at end | first at end) = 2/5
after second end removed, remaining row of 4 with 2 ends
P(third leaver at end | previous at ends) = 2/4
after third end removed, remaining row of 3 with 2 ends
P(fourth leaver at end | previous at ends) = 2/3
after fourth end removed, remaining row of 2; both are ends, P(fifth at end | previous) = 2/2 = 1
after fifth, last student; P=1
P(some student has to pass by another) = 43/45
P(some student has to pass by another | (f(1) + 23/4) students in row, random finish times) = ?
